Getting Started
Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see https://quarto.org.
Quarto can render in real-time code written using VS Code, Jupyter, RStudio, Neovim, and (text) Editor. For this presentation, weâ€™ll focus on how Quarto can improve our lives in RStudio.
Quarto works by using knitr to execute your code chunks and create a markdown document (.md). This document is then processed by pandoc into your format of choice.
Step 1: Download Quarto
You can find the link to download here: https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/
Step 2: Choose your tool
Weâ€™ll be using Quarto in RStudio. Starting is as easy as opening RStudio and selecting â€œQuarto Documentâ€ or â€œQuarto Presentation,â€ depending on your preference, just as you would â€œR markdown.â€ The extension of the document will be â€œ.qmdâ€ rather than â€œ.rmdâ€.

text:
Running Code
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can create chunks as you would in .rmd, or select an Executable Cell from the â€œInsertâ€ tab. Quarto can create executable cells in many languages, including RCpp.
Note in this presentation, I added a â€œcode-fold: trueâ€ beneath the â€œformat: html:â€ in the YAML to hide the code.
I also added â€œcode-link: trueâ€. This generates hyperlinks for all your commands, which can be a great resource for students following your code.
In your code chunk, you can still include output specifications (like â€œmessage = FALSEâ€) in the header as done in .rmd files, OR you can use â€œ#|â€ to make adjustments to your output and figures.

Codelibrary(tidyverse)

library(palmerpenguins)

In the code chunk below, I used

#| label: fig-my-chunk
#| fig-cap: This is my figure caption.
#| fig-cap-location: bottom
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-asp: 0.618
#| fig-alt: This text will appear when I select the attributes of my figure.

       aes(x = bill_length_mm,
           y = bill_depth_mm,
           color = species,
           shape = species

  geom_point() +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_color_colorblind() +

Presentations
If youâ€™d like to make a Quarto presentation instead, itâ€™s fairly similar, where your headers will indicate new slides in the presentation. These titles are available to preview in your Outline to the right of the visual editor.
You can edit the â€œ|# output-location:â€ in the code chunk to format your figures with your codes on the slides, or use â€œ|# output-location: slideâ€ to have your figure appear on the slide following the code.
If your code/text is too large for your slide, you can use the Outline to access the chunk attributes and adjust text size, too. Or, text color. Thatâ€™s how I made this chunk blue!
